settings.blog-title: HOW TO CLEANSE AND ORGANIZE YOUR WARDROBE

settings.text: As natural as sleep is, it certainly isn’t easy to master. After all, how long has it been since you got a genuinely good night’s sleep? Technology, artificial light and our 24/7 lifestyles have made it harder than ever for us to switch off at night. And with sleep being tied so closely to our overall health, so many of us pursue the perfect eight hours; but how do you turn that from a dream into reality?

settings.grid-content:
Know your exits

Before you start, have a plan in place for where all your discarded items are going to go. Some pieces will be unwearable or damaged beyond repair, these are destined for throwing. Others may be in excellent condition but just aren’t in your favour anymore, and these can either be donated to charity or resold. Avoid moving your discarded clothes from one area of your home to another, and have a clear plan in place.

Lay it all out

There’s no other way to begin than to dive in at the deep end. Start by removing everything - and we mean everything - from your physical wardrobe. That includes clothes, shoes, accessories, and even handbags.

Place all items into categories: tops in one pile, sweaters in another, trousers over there, etc. This is the best way to spot repeat purchases or identical pieces that you have collected over the years. What’s great about this process is that you can rediscover long-forgotten gems to wear again.

This may be a long process, but trust us and stick with it.

settings.text:
Ask the difficult questions

Once you can see all your clothes laid out in front of you, it’s time to ask the difficult questions. Some ideas:

Have I worn this in the past year? The past two?

Does this still fit me?

Would I buy this if I saw it today?

Will I ever actually fix that button?

If you find yourself answering ‘no’ to any of the above, transfer the piece in question to your donate, resell or chuck pile.

settings.grid-content:
Does it bring me joy?

We understand that clothes can have real sentimental value, which is why we take a caveat from organising connoisseur, Marie Kondo. If you come across an item that brings you true joy - even if it rarely sees the light of day - don’t toss it. Instead, perhaps spend some energy and money bringing it back to life. Replace buttons, repair broken zips and store it properly.

Try everything on

If you don’t have time for this, it’s perfectly fine to skip this step and trust that you know your size and shape. However, it can be useful to explore how you look and feel in clothes you may have forgotten about. It may look fantastic hanging in your closet, but how does it make you feel when you wear it? Before you look at whether it fits well or not, consider your confidence and happiness in it first.

Re-hang correctly

With the pieces you have chosen to keep, take some time to store them all in the best possible way. Organise items into their own drawers and fold neatly so as to minimise creases, and in a way that allows you to see exactly what’s on offer. Store pieces properly. For example, always fold your cashmere, and keep items such as dresses and shirts hung to avoid creases. Your shoes and handbags should be stored in their boxes and original dust bags wherever possible to prevent dust gathering.

Invest in high quality wooden hangers and organise your clothes according to type or colour. As you slowly rebuild your wardrobe, you will be able to spot any gaps which need to be filled. Perhaps it’s the perfect luxury cashmere sweater or staple trousers that will complete your edit.

Rotate throughout the year

There will be some pieces that, for six months of the year, don’t see the light of day. Your sun dresses and sandals, for example, won’t be used from at least September to April; perhaps longer with the unpredictability of British weather. It’s no good looking through your clothes in the depths of winter only to be faced with short summer dresses. To make the most of your available space, have a system in place that sees you rotate seasonal clothes between your closet and drawers and perhaps boxes in the attic or underneath your bed. That way, you can limit your organisation sessions to twice a year.

settings.text:
Be the gateway

Don’t let your hard work go to waste by re-filling your newly detoxed closet as soon as the sales arrive. If you’re truly committed to keeping your wardrobe lean and organised, you could adopt a one-in, one-out policy, or simply track your spending and keep notes on which pieces you already have.

But, if you come across something that fills you with joy, then by all means invest.
